facts.text: Chajoo Ram, appellant, was elected Sarpanch of the Nyaya Panchayat of Risia Bazar, Tehsil Nanpara, District Bahraich on October 29, 1956.
Radhey Shyam, respondent, who was defeated in the election, filed an election petition which was dismissed on June 3, 1958.
During the trial of the election petition, an injunction was issued restraining the appellant from functioning as Sarpanch, in force from December 3, 1956 to December 10, 1957.
After dismissal of election petition, appellant started functioning as Sarpanch.
Radhey Shyam filed complaints to District Magistrate alleging irregularities by appellant, no action taken.

Radhey Shyam filed writ petition W.P. No. 89 of 1960 in Allahabad High Court for mandamus directing enquiries into complaints, allowed on September 4, 1961, directing District Magistrate and Sub-Divisional Magistrate to hold enquiry, leaving public interest to them.

In para 10 of affidavit dated July 6, 1960 filed by appellant in writ proceedings: 'That the deponent was not acting as a Sarpanch till 7th December, 1957, when he was given over charge of the office of Sarpanch by opposite party No. 4 Chhotey Lal Sahayak Sarpanch.' Except mentioned cases, others entrusted by Sahayak Sarpanch under court orders.
Paras 9 and 10 of Radhey Shyam's affidavit dated March 28, 1960 alleged Sarpanch referred cases to special bench, allotted unevenly, did not inform dates, participated without being member.
Appellant's reply to para 9 in affidavit July 6, 1960: No dispute on procedure, it is a new amendment.
Rejoinder affidavit by Radhey Shyam dated July 15, 1960, para 8: Denied appellant not acting as Sarpanch till Dec 7, 1957; he acted throughout in violation of stay order; referred cases himself.

Appellant's counter-affidavit dated July 24, 1960: Not acting as Sarpanch on June 6, 1957; annexure 34 written by B.P. Joshi, Mantri; Chhotey Lal out on June 3, 1957, asked deponent to do ministerial work.
Radhey Shyam's further rejoinder July 24, 1960: Nothing new on this point.
Radhey Shyam moved application under s.476 CrPC on December 10, 1962 for appellant's prosecution.
Single Judge order dated January 27, 1964 directed complaint against appellant for false statement in para 10 of affidavit July 6, 1960.
Division Bench affirmed single Judge on March 13, 1968 re para 10.
Enquiry by Sub-Divisional Magistrate Nageshwar Singh dated January 4, 1963: Appellant committed irregularities without dishonest motive, no action needed.
District Magistrate on February 17, 1963 desired further probe; K.P. Mathur endorsed no mala fide, irregularities due to inexperience.
Appellant affidavit December 8, 1961 in those proceedings: Not acted as Sarpanch for one year, Chhotey Lal looked after work.
Radhey Shyam applied under s.476 CrPC to District Magistrate for prosecution under ss.193,181,182 IPC; District Magistrate on May 4, 1964 held no case, discharged notice.
Sessions Judge upheld District Magistrate, possibility of conviction remote.
Revision to High Court against Sessions Judge dismissed (informed at bar, not in record).

Evidence relied: Four receipts nos. 39-42 and report to Panchayat Raj Officer; receipts 59,60 June 4, 1957; 61 June 6, 1957; 77 June 4, 1957; report June 6, 1957 with appellant's signature as Sarpanch.
Appellant's explanation: Sahayak Sarpanch on leave June 4-11, 1957; did ministerial work; Secretary inserted 'Sarpanch' formally.

legal_issues.text: Whether proceedings under s.476 CrPC are barred by s.479A CrPC as appellant filed affidavit but did not appear as witness.
Whether appellant made deliberately false statement in para 10 of affidavit dated July 6, 1960 that he had not been acting as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957, warranting prosecution under s.476 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.476 barred by s.479A CrPC.
Explanation plausible: Did ministerial work only when Sahayak Sarpanch on leave; not acting as Sarpanch; receipts not exclusive to Sarpanch; Secretary inserted word formally.
District Magistrate and Sessions Judge found no case for prosecution; long lapse of time.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant acted as Sarpanch throughout in violation of stay order, as per receipts 39-42 and report; false denial in para 10.
Explanation not given earlier in affidavits under s.476 or supplementary.

court_reasoning.text: s.479A inapplicable as appellant did not appear as witness before court; filing affidavit does not amount to appearing as witness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only witness appearing before court covered by s.479A.

court_reasoning.text: Receipts nos. 59,60,61,77 do not prove acting as Sarpanch; no evidence Panch could not sign; Sahayak on leave, ministerial work allowed.

court_reasoning.key_observation: Does not prove intent to act as Sarpanch.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution for perjury only if deliberate, conscious, conviction reasonably probable; prima facie deliberate falsehood on matter of substance; here material inadequate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approach must not be mechanical; consider prior enquiries by DM/SDM/Sessions finding no case.

court_reasoning.text: Long delay over 10 years, pendency since 1962 militates against expediency.

holdings.text: s.479A does not bar s.476 proceedings as no appearance as witness.
No prima facie case of deliberate false statement; inexpedient in interests of justice to file complaint.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing prosecution for false evidence; s.479A overrides but inapplicable as no witness appearance.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Sections for which prosecution sought for false affidavit.

statutes_cited.name: Panchayat Raj Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure violated alleged; Mantri's duty to ensure compliance.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Division Bench directing complaint for para 10 of affidavit set aside; no prosecution as inexpedient.

key_quotes.text: The crucial point to be noticed in this section is that it is only a witness who has appeared before the court who can be proceeded against.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Prosecution for perjury should be sanctioned by courts only in those cases where the perjury appears to be deliberate and conscious and the conviction is reasonably probable or likely.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for ordering prosecution under s.476.

key_quotes.text: No doubt giving of false evidence and filing false affidavit is an evil which must be effectively curbed with a strong hand but to start prosecution for perjury too readily and too frequently without due care and caution and on inconclusive and doubtful material defeats its very purpose.
key_quotes.speaker: court
